description: First attested in English in 1646: from Latin ambilaevus (ambi- (“both”) + laevus (“left”)), a calque of Ancient Greek ἀμφαρίστερος (ampharísteros, “with two left hands, awkward, clumsy”) from ἀμφί (amphí, “on both sides”) + ἀριστερός (aristerós, “left”).

adjectives.description: ambilevous (comparative more ambilevous, superlative most ambilevous)

entries.meaning: (rare) Having equally bad ability in both hands; clumsy; butterfingered.
